author: Bahá'u'lláh
source_text: و او را بر بستر ناکامی انداخته مردمانی که از بادهٴ خودبینی سرمست شده‌اند پزشک دانا را از او بازداشته‌اند اینست که خود و همهٴ مردمان را گرفتار نموده‌اند نه درد میدانند نه درمان میشناسند راست را کژ انگاشته‌اند و دوست را دشمن شمرده‌اند بشنوید آواز این زندانی را بایستید و بگوئید
translation: We can well perceive how the whole human race is encompassed with great, with incalculable afflictions. We see it languishing on its bed of sickness, sore-tried and disillusioned. They that are intoxicated by self-conceit have interposed themselves between it and the Divine and infallible Physician. Witness how they have entangled all men, themselves included, in the mesh of their devices. They can neither discover the cause of the disease, nor have they any knowledge of the remedy. They have conceived the straight to be crooked, and have imagined their friend an enemy.

terms.note: Root means 'much; many; very; greatly' but SE renders as 'bed' here — a metaphorical innovation absent from the 5 documented occurrences where 'many' or 'How strange' dominate.
Consistent with its lone semantic rendering across corpus. Unique usage in context of self-conceit intoxication, emphasizing spiritual derangement rather than literal drunkenness.

terms.literal: captive, afflicted, troubled, caught; affliction, trouble
terms.note: Root primary sense is 'captive; afflicted; caught.' SE chooses 'entangled' here, distinct from typical 'encompassed' or 'hath enveloped' renderings in the 5-occurrence pattern.
Root fundamentally means 'truth; verily' but SE renders 'straight' — geometrical abstraction unique to this passage, departing from abstract truth-framings in 6-occurrence standard.
Standard rendering as 'Prisoner' appears in 7-occurrence pattern. Here applied to the Manifestation, a referential shift that transforms metaphorical captivity into divine confinement.
